bibl.title: Letter from Amory H. Hutchinson to Mabel H. Lazear, January 6, 1936

div1.p: Hutchinson describes the play she has written, based upon the work of the Yellow Fever Commission.

div1.head: Letter from Amory H. Hutchinson to Mabel H. Lazear, January 6, 1936
div1.opener:
January 6th 1936 Rocky Spring Farm
Media, Pa
AMORY HARE
My dear Mrs Lazear:
div1.p:
Mr Dougherty of the
Franklin Institute has sent me your
gracious letter of December 27th, re-
lative to my play HARD BARGAIN, which
the Institute is considering putting
on the air in a series of dramas portray-
ing the dramatic incidents in the lives
of great American men of Science.

The circumstances in con-
nection with my writing this play are
these:

My Father, Dr Hobart Amory Hare,
immortalized for me the story of your
husband's achievements while at Johns
Hopkins, and when the news of his death
reached him he told me the circumstances
of it in a way that at once made Jesse
Lazear the enshrined recollection of
my youth.

When the world began to accept
my work in poetry and fiction, I thought
constantly of the day when I could con-
sider myself sufficiently skilled in the
use of English to do justice to the
great theme offered in the facts of
Lazear s sacrifice. And in 1932
I began seeking such data as was available
as a nucleus for the drama I was at-
tempting to write.

Dr Thayer was of enormous help
to me due to the fact that he had
personally known both you and Dr La-
AMORY HARE zear and was possessed of much tech-
nical information, as well as some
notes of your husband's and some
drawings of the intestines of the
deadly mosquitos. Out of my talks
with him I drew a sort of pattern or
impression, and this was adapted to
the needs of the stage.

I need hardly tell you that
these needs are such that the play
makes no pretense of being an his-
torical document in the sequence of
events governing Dr Lazear's life,
but it, at the same time, is entire-
ly authentic as to the salient oc-
currences and events. I have had it
read by many medical men besides
Dr Thayer and Dr Young, Dr Packard,
and Dr DeSchweinitz, all of whom have
commended the technical authenticity
and been unstinting in praise of the
finished production.

Your own part in the story
has been, of necessity, purely im-
aginary, but Katharine Cornell was
so moved by it that she wrote me
regretting that it was not possible
to create a female 'lead' in this
drama, due to the fact that the story
is obviously for an actor in the
leading role.

AMORY HARE Now comes the distressing part of
why the play has not been produced.
My agents, Pinker and Morrison, at
once pronounced it a perfect script
and at Miss Cornell's request, sent it
to Mr McClintic. Mr McClintic wrote
asking if he might keep it to reread,
and again wrote in praise of it. He
kept the play until one month before
YELLOW JACK appeared, written by Mr
McClintic and Mr Sidney Howard. While
YELLOW JACK was in preparation the press
published announcements that it would
appear shortly, and that Mr Howard had
intended writing the play for twenty
years but had only recently been able
to acquire sufficient data to undertake
it.

Imagine my feelings when YELLOW JACK
appeared and Dr Lazear was given no
part whatsoever in the action. In this
play the whole credit is given to
Dr Reed.

I have been insuch a ferment of
protest ever since that I have long since
ceased worrying over my play's having
become obsolete through the subject's
being covered by YELLOW JACK. My agents
have submitted the play to numberless
actors and producers, all of whom ex-
claim 'this is a far more powerful and
human drama than YELLOW JACK---why was'
nt it produced instead of YELLOW JACK?”

They have advised waiting until YEL-
LOW JACK is not such a recent recollec-
tion on Broadway, or producing HARD BAR-
GAIN on a western circuit, as YELLOW JACK
ran but three weeks, and never left
NEw York. For my part I only want that
4.
the American people shall know where
AMORY HARE the credit belongs. And I am hoping
that a production will ultimately
be possible.

Meanwhile Mr Dougherty will send
you the script, or I will have it sent
direct from my agents. And I sincerely
hope there will be nothing to offend
your sensibilities in its portrayal.
Without your approval of its release
I could not consider its reaching the
public, either on the air, or behind
the footlights.

Please let me tell you with what
a sense of relief I now possess your
wherabouts. With your address in my
pocket I feel somehow fortified in the
hope of getting the recognition due
Dr Lazear. Of him, it seems to me might
be said what Sir Berkeley Moynihan
said of Lawrence Oates who went with
Scott to the Antarctic and walked de-
liberately away to die alone in the icy
wastes to lighten the burden of his
comrades “This was the greatest act
of lonely heroism in the annals of
our country.”
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, Amory Hare Hutchinson Mrs. J.P. Hutchinson
